practice.title: This Is Going to Change
agreedSteps: Use the mantra 'This is going to change' or 'This is uncertain' throughout the day — apply it to everything: good experiences, bad experiences, boring experiences, the whole thing.
Let this naturally cultivate a sense of peace. The more we attune to uncertainty, the more we realize our peaceful mind and virtues are the only reliable tools for navigating it.
steps: Notice the suffering of uncertainty when it arises — the worry, the anxiety of not knowing what will happen — and name it: 'That's the suffering of uncertainty.'
When something bad or unexpected happens, catch it: 'That's the suffering of uncertainty. All friends will leave at some point. All conditions will change.'
If resistance comes up, check three questions: (1) Do I really want to overcome my attachment? (2) Do I believe I can? (3) Do I have a mental image of what non-attachment looks like that I love?
practice.quote: If we just subtracted all the discontented thoughts in our life, there's a natural, beautiful contentment in our heart.

commentary.title: Affectionate Love: Warm, Close, Friendly
content: The next stage in developing bodhichitta is affectionate love. Geshe-la uses three words: warm, close, friendly. Each has a slightly different connotation — warmth is the quality of the mind, closeness is that intimate feeling of being totally at ease, and friendliness is delight at seeing someone.

There's a continuum here. Equanimity is the first step — the most basic version of warm, close, friendly, where we've simply let go of anger, attachment, and indifference. Then viewing beings as mother takes it further. Then remembering their kindness. Then wanting to repay that kindness. This stage is like the crystallized maximum version — the full effect of all those previous causes.
Think of the previous four stages as causes, and this stage as the effect. It's just really trying to hold and maintain that full-hearted closeness and affection.
commentary.quote: It's nice just to use this little checklist. Warm, close, friendly. What's it like to be warm towards this person, close to them, friendly with them?

commentary.title: Great Compassion: A Love Issue, Never a Compassion Issue
content: Great compassion wishes every being to be free from all suffering — and the Buddhist view always encompasses future lives. We're not just wishing someone out of temporary misery. We're wishing them to be free of samsara and its causes.

If compassion doesn't arise easily, work backwards. The issue is in affectionate love. If affectionate love isn't there, check the stage before that. You can always diagnose by stepping back one stage at a time. It's like yogurt and milk — no milk, no yogurt. There's no shortcut.
Most of our compassion issues are actually love issues. The only other possibility is a renunciation issue. It's never actually a compassion issue.
commentary.quote: Most of our compassion issues are love issues. There's one other type: a renunciation issue. It's never actually a compassion issue.

commentary.title: The Malice Warning
content: Anytime we delight in someone's suffering or bad news — even if we think 'but they're really bad' — that's malice. It's the opposite of Buddhist thinking. And it's everywhere right now. It doesn't matter where you land on any political spectrum. This kind of thinking is on all sides.

If we let that influence us — reading things, following people who celebrate the downfall of others — we are undermining our bodhichitta and our whole path. Have a wisdom fear around any influence that supports this way of thinking. Be extremely wary of exposing your mind to it.

commentary.title: Guarding the Doors of the Senses
content: There are three causes of delusion: the karmic seed, the object, and inappropriate attention. Ultimately we need to remove the seeds. Until then, we work on inappropriate attention. But if the object is just instantly stimulating delusion, we can temporarily remove it.

This isn't weakness — it's creating space to gather strength, get wiser, more loving, happier, so we can eventually engage from that strength. Geshe-la calls it a supreme way to practice moral discipline. Either remove the object or change the inappropriate attention. And it's not forever — just for the time we need.

commentary.title: Renunciation as Joy: The Domino Chain
content: Non-attachment isn't the absence of attachment. A baby has absence of attachment for alcohol — that's not non-attachment. Non-attachment is a virtuous mental factor that actively opposes attachment. And it's incredibly happy. No feelings of 'I need to be different,' 'I wish things were like this.' If we were just us, minus all those discontented thoughts, we'd basically already be incredibly happy.

There's a domino chain: thinking about samsara's sufferings → opposing attachment → wanting to leave → putting in effort → actually leaving → ending suffering forever. A huge moment in our spiritual life is when we start to love thinking about the sufferings of samsara — because of where it leads.

If thinking about suffering feels depressing, that's our attachment — Stockholm Syndrome for our prison. We're defensive of it. Check three questions: Do I really want to overcome my attachment? Do I believe I can? Do I have a mental image of what freedom looks like?
commentary.quote: If we were just us, minus all the discontented thoughts in our life, we'd basically already be incredibly happy.

commentary.title: The Suffering of Uncertainty
content: There are six general sufferings that pervade every realm: uncertainty, no satisfaction, leaving our body repeatedly, taking rebirth repeatedly, losing status repeatedly, no companionship. These are our guarantees no matter where we go in samsara.

In samsara, no condition is certain. High status turns into servitude, beauty changes like a flower in autumn, wealth is lost as if merely lent. Friendships are fragile — it takes only a few words to destroy trust. We're constantly switching places with the people around us, life after life.

When we stop expecting certainty, we actually feel lighter. Then we get interested in the real question: what will actually help me navigate uncertainty? Not money, not health, not property — a peaceful mind and virtues. That's the only reliable investment.
commentary.quote: This is gonna change, it's gonna change. The good, the bad, the neutral, the whole thing. Let's really try to attune to it.

commentary.title: What We Do Is Important
content: The word 'important' is almost a technical term. When we meditate on equalizing self and others, we think: you are important. Your happiness and freedom are important. There's a sense of weight here — not heavy, but impactful.

What we do is important. When we meditate, it's really important. When we love others, it's really important. This sense of things — that our practice and our community touch people's lives in real, lasting ways, even across lifetimes — can be profoundly motivating. Just use it as a mantra: what we do is important.
commentary.quote: What we do here is really important. It's not just a trite, fun thing we're up to. It's actually really important.
